content.description: Little Nuts followes the left trending seem and starts in a small corner with small nuts and wire placements available. After the first 25 ft the angle decreases to a moderate grade to the two bolt chain anchor.
content.protection: Standard rack, Extra small nuts / wires, 2 bolt chain anchor.
content.location: This route is located in the small corner 15 ft up hill from the upper aret.

content.description: This route starts in the awkward stemming corner with good jugs but bad feet. Continue on good holds up a right trending crack with small gear. The upper section climbs the face on slightly run out yet easy terrain before breaking right at the topout and walking to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the right of two routes that start off of this  belay platform.

content.description: Sendsational is the hardest trad line at the crag and consists of steep climbing up a left trending dihedral. Pull through a bulg 20 feet off the ground and continue to a small ledge halfway up the technical face. Shake out and finish a few more technical moves before scrambling right on easy ground to a two bolt chain anchor.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", 2 bolt chain anchor.
content.location: This route is the uppermost prominent dihedral at the 101 crag.

content.description: This is the prominent inside corner that is located above a large, rocky belay area. Start by scrambling onto a small pinnacle at the base of the route and continue up a quality finger crack for 10 feet. At this point, the inside corner split into a unique chimney dihedral that offers many different styles and movement to progress up the middle section of the route. Pull through a crux section before reaching a serious of ledges that make for a great shake out or you may choose to finish strong and continue the fight straight up the cracks below the two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Standard rack to 4", optional 5" & 6"  2 bolt chain anchor.
content.location: This climb is the left of two prominent dihedrals located at the cliff.

content.description: This climb consist of difficult move for the first 10 feet above a rocky landing. A couple try cams or TCU's custard together is it good strategy to protect a from ground fall. Continue straight up the crack with good gear into a notch. Follow the skyline up and right to a 2 bolt anchor. Bonus points for staying on the face and traversing through this deep moves below the anchor.
content.protection: Standard rack, two bolt chain anchor.
content.location: This route starts on the Left End of the Crag above a scree field. Stand on top of the large block to plug your first pieces of gear in order to prevent a potential ground fall on the Crux moves.

content.description: One Move Wonder starts in a thin seem above a ledge. Stuff a number of small Stoppers or rp's into the thin crack in an awkward fashion to protect the first 10 feet of climbing. The route get this name from this beginning sequence. Continue  up the left trending crack to the top of the cliff 30ft off the deck and follow the ramp right to a fix anchor that is shared with two other routes on this wall.
content.protection: Standard rack, extra small nuts / wires
content.location: This route starts at the Left End of the Crag at a small seam. You can belay from the approach Trail or a rock ledge at the base of the route.

content.description: This hand crack is a perfect place for someone to learn how to place traditional gear due to the extremely moderate nature of the route. Pull a couple steep moves at the start then continue to follow the extremely predictable feature to the top of the Cliff where you'll find a 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: Standard Rack to 3", 2 Bolt Chain Anchor
content.location: This route is the obvious hand crack located on the left side of the Crag.

content.description: This finger dihedral follows the right trending inside corner that takes lots of good gear on low angle rock. Halfway up the route you will pull onto face moves and continue straight up to a two bolt fixed anchor that is shared with two other routes on the wall.
content.location: This route is located on the left side of the wall near the place where the approach Trail meets the cliff.

content.description: This left leaning finger crack is one of the most obvious line on the wall. Follow it on Cam's and nuts halfway up the cliff to a ledge that used to contain the capstone. From here you can stem up and follow the ridge or take the proud line and continue on the face out right with great hands and shit feet. Plug a medium sized cam into the discontinued crack before reaching the dihedral and pulling onto ledge containing a 2 bolt anchor at the top of the cliff.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", 2 bolt chain anchor.
content.location: This is the obvious crack up the main wall

content.description: Place a number of wires and small nuts to protect the crux sequence and continue to a light colored section of wall where a large flake was removed during development. After the halfway mark you will gain easier ground and cruise up to a two bolt anchor.
content.protection: Standard rack, extra small nuts / wires, two bolt chain anchor.
content.location: This thin seem is located 6 feet right of the aret in the middle of the crag.

content.description: This route starts on a awkward boulder problem with sloping hands and shitty feet, then follows a left trending seem. On a positive side, this start move is portectable or avoidable by starting on the belay ledge to the right. Continue on extremely moderate ground up a staircase with lots of gear potential.
content.protection: Standard rack, 2 bolt the chain anchor.
content.location: This route is located on the right side of the Crag.

content.description: This route climbs the right most crack on the face that runs parallel to a similar left trending seam to its left. The climb is more of a staircase with  heaps of gear placement potential. It is a perfect route to learn how to place nuts and cams.
content.location: This is the right most face climb on the main wall.

content.description: The 101 Crag is the result of a spectacular team effort throughout the summer of 2019. A number of Route development 101 clinics were hosted here, sharing a behind-the-scenes experience of what opening up new lines in the chugach entail. Over the course of 300 plus hours , this Crag was transformed from a vegetated, choss pile into an enjoyable climbing area that hosts Trad routes from 5.5 to 5.12 The wall receives Early Morning Sun in the spring and summer yet generally stays in the shade due to the North facing direction of the cliff. Believe it or not, on a sunny day the shade can be a welcoming site on Thompson Pass :-)
